passages.text: Exploring the Healthineer spin scenario debate

We published a comprehensive cross- asset and cross- team note on Siemens last week (link) which has been generally well received by investors, who are 1) typically in agreement that a RemainCo SIE screens attractively from a relative growth versus peers standpoint, 2) uniformly in agreement that the SHL multiple is currently depressed due to the overhang of a potential separation, and 3) generally unclear about how the mechanics of a separation would work and what the associated tax implications would be, due to a lack of precedent in Germany. We seek to address point 3 as best we can in the absence of precedent, noting that nobody (including the company) can be certain how this would be structured, yet.

What we know: SHL's current market value is 53bn, of which the SIE holding is \(73\%\) or 39bn. Both of these figures would be higher were it not for this overhang, our assessment suggests \(30\%\) or 16bn and 12bn, respectively. Embedded within our SIE price target of 300 is a \(10\%\) /25bn discount/provision to account for the hard to quantify separation costs associated with such a complex transaction. Despite this, we see \(30\%\) upside.

Full spin scenario: We have highlighted that a full spin of the \(73\%\) in SHL would be a blue- sky scenario, which would essentially be tax free and in our view, the best outcome for SIE shareholders. It would however be quite uncharacteristic of Siemens, and all the other large cap EU industrials we follow, to be quite so shareholder friendly. If this happens, the longstanding debate about SIE's relative capital deployment track- record should be turned upside down and re- rate multiples. Clearly, Siemens doesn't need to retain a stake per se, nor does it require any cash proceeds from such a transaction, which we explored extensively in last week's note. The only downside we see would be temporary and stem from the fact that the SHL free- float would instantly be c4x current levels, which is good for structural multiples but would likely lead to significant volatility initially.

Divi- in- kind: We have assumed that SIE would distribute c 2/3rds of it's c 39bn position (27bn) as a dividend- in- kind, in order to retain future optionality (12bn). There is no precedent for this, but we assume this is more a function of its inefficient tax consequences, as this would result in a c7bn tax bill (paid by Siemens to the German tax authorities, some of which could be recouped by investors depending on jurisdiction) resulting in a lesser c 20 distribution, as opposed to there being a regulatory barrier that we know of. There are also multi- year liability considerations associated with a retained stake, which would make it less attractive still. In our view, there are smarter ways to structure a process like this, but the 25bn provision in our PT is materially in excess of a potential 7bn tax bill and the overhang of having a retained stake. This scenario would, however, lead to less SHL volatility due to a smaller proportion of transient SHL holders versus a full spin.
Blocks: Block placements of the current SHL position, which is already depressed by 12bn in our assessment, would arguably be less value- creative
SIEGn.F, SIE GR Price (29 Aug 25): 237.10 Price Target (Dec- 26): 300.00
than the dividend-in-kind approach, even when accounting for a large tax bill, and would likely add further pressure to the SHL shares in the first instance.

- The pension fund: Siemens previously transferred a large portion of its Siemens Energy (ENR) shares to its pension fund in 2024, in order to strengthen its pension assets in Germany, and at one point Siemens' pension fund owned c20% of ENR. In theory a similar approach could be used for SHL, prior to a tax free spin of the balance. Whilst this wouldn't result in cash for SIE, it would result in a change to SIE leverage by virtue of the pension deficit, but this is already at an all time low of c€0.8bn, as of Q3'25.

- Split off: While we cannot find a precedent of this in Germany either, Siemens could potentially offer its shareholders the opportunity to exchange some or all of their shares for shares in SHL. Because this would be an optional exchange, the distribution of the SHL shares would not be proportional to the current holdings, unlike a spin. As well as being tax free, this approach would mean that new SHL holders would be deliberate owners as opposed to potentially transient investors, reducing SHL volatility. There would be a cost / value transfer of course, as the parent would typically incentivise shareholders to opt for an exchange, which on the basis of what we have seen in the US examples would be a c7-10% discount (i.e. €3bn at current levels) versus a VWAP period.

- A NewCo distribution: Some investors have mooted the idea of Siemens creating a holding company NewCo of some kind, to which the 73% SHL holding could be transferred and instead of distributing SHL shares directly, the company could instead spin e.g. 2/3rds of the NewCo, to minimise tax leakage whilst retaining future optionality. In our view this would be tax efficient but a relatively clunky option.

- Conclusion: There are many structures which are inevitably being considered and the ultimate outcome will be known soon enough, most likely disclosed at the CMD on 9 Dec. Regardless of the structure, we cannot foresee a scenario in which the tax cost, leakage or value transfer would come close to the €25bn provision already embedded in our assessment of fair value. Put another way, the valuation unlock from a SHL separation will ultimately offer differing levels of upside and SHL volatility depending on how tax efficient management want to make this process. In absolute terms, the figures involved are large, but disproportionally small versus the value unlock potential and when put in the context of the current market value. Given that the company has been carrying out a detailed assessment of this complex topic for the better part of a year, they will be very well informed on all of the above, and more, and will make an informed decision based on the long term interests of all stakeholders, in our view.
Figure 1: Summarising potential options, costs and considerations
Source: J.P. Morgan estimates
Siemens (Overweight; Price Target: €300.00)

- Portfolio strategy. The eight-year portfolio simplification effort, which started with the debatable 'fleet of ships' strategy, is almost complete. Whilst painfully slow at times, it has unequivocally resulted in a better business with higher growth prospects, higher gross and operating margins and more predictable FCF. The shareholding in SHL (73% or €40bn) is the next and perhaps final step in this journey, which we expect to be addressed at the CMD.- Strong core. Siemens' exposure to automation, software, electrification and mobility is attractive in the current context and should deliver above sector average organic growth on a multi-year view.- Focus moves to execution. After years of structural change and higher investments, Siemens is entering a period where the focus moves to execution, driving growth and improving margins, returns and cash.- Valuation support. Siemens is attractively valued on both an absolute and relative basis.

We set our December 2026 price target using a detailed Sum- of- the- Parts model, which includes our top- ranked Med Tech tech team's view on the fair value of SHL, which is some \(30\%\) above the current value. We also compare the implied RemainCo fair value with the growth outlook of peers on a PEG adjusted basis, to ensure validity. We see this as a pragmatic approach at this juncture as opposed to the traditional approach, which at moments like these can result in further discounting to already discounted multiples in the case of SHL and DI which is at the trough of a cycle on trough margins.

J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex- Australia and ex- India) and U.K. small- and mid- cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analysts' coverage universe. If it does not appear in the Important Disclosures section of this report, the certifying Research Analyst's coverage universe can be found on J.P. figures.title: Summarising potential options, costs and considerations

series.name: Pros
values: SIE retain significant optionality. and lesser volatility for SHL
Maximising optionality for SIE future reinvestment
Limited cost, lowest SHL volatility outcome
Tax free, full SHL free float (+ve for structural multiples)
Low cost, positive for pension, lesser volatility for SHL

series.name: Cons
values: Significant tax cost but still unlocks significant value + potential for investor tax rebates
High volatility at SHL in first instance. Less optionality for SIE
